items.content_html:
Project Summary

The Institute for Digital Culture is a pioneering research centre in helping cultural sectors adapt to digital transformation. They planned to establish research hubs in different regions. I acted as a research assistant to pilot a study that paved the way for the first hub, the "Digital Culture Observatory". It reviewed existing research strategies on digital activities in cultural institutions, and envisioned a series of future-oriented policies and strategies.

Goal

To review the current landscape of cross-sectoral and cross-institutional research collaborations within cultural institutions. As one of the Institute's first research projects with their partners, the goal is to pave the way for establishing the Observatory - a research hub dedicated to digital culture in Australia.

My Role
  • Strategic analysis & development
  • Literature review¬†

Methods

Scoping Review

I led a review of research strategies related to technology R&D in 30+ cultural institutions, examining their outputs and impact.¬†Using insights garnered from this exploration, the team formulated practical guidelines for both practice and action research tailored to cultural institutions in Australia.

Key Insights

Based on the scoping review, I developed a taxonomy of human-centred research strategies:

  • Practice-based Research fosters co-creation and experimentation in museums.
  • Applied Research uses evidence-informed evaluation to drive the development of impactful solutions, creating tangible benefits for individuals and communities in the long term.
  • Participatory Research promotes community engagement and social change. It is the fundation of human-centred research .
  • Innovative Research Translation challenges conventional research strategies. Using multisensory technologies as creative mediums, it expands the accessibility and reach of research outcomes.

Impact¬†

The research supported Monash University and the Australian National University in curating a seminar series that built digital research capacity. It initiated partnerships between the Institute for Digital Culture and Australian cultural sectors.

items.content_html:
üëã Hi, I am Han. I research and design the human side of digital transformation.

When I was a curator intern, I uncovered a lot of biased legacy data in the collection database. I created the first spreadsheet at that museum to survey these entries. I translated it into an inclusive research guideline that changed the way other staff used sensitive data.¬†

This is what I do: I design systems to get people embracing positive change.

I started my PhD when "AI" and "Web 3" became buzzwords. Industries rapidly adopted these technological solutions without considering their implications. These include organisations with traditional business models, where implementing new technology is often considered ‚Äúchallenging‚Äù. So far, I have interviewed 9 organisations to identify their challenges. I am developing a workbook that enhances organisational learning on implications and requirements for digital transformation, and to help them make informed decisions that drive success.¬†

My experience in cultural & creative industries taught me to be people-centred. In 2023, I brought 2 award-winning cultural education apps to life, making art accessible to people with diverse cognition needs. I streamlined innovative workflows in UX teams, integrating gen-AI tools in persona research and prototyping.

I lead research to inform decision making. When I worked as a research assistant, I identified research centre's needs for expanded digital inclusion and strategic collaboration, helping it establish effective partnerships with international stakeholders.

I use interviews, surveys, contextual inquiry, and textual analysis to understand how human beings make meanings in systems around them. I only conduct research when it creates solutions that have social impact. I know how to work with product experts, engineers, and data scientists.

I advocate for digital infrastructure to be collaborative, beyond organisational or national silos. I have lectured at universities and conferences worldwide to help people discover opportunities for collaboration and catalysts for change.¬†

I love experiments, trust-building, and exchange - they empower us to better dwell in this world.

You can view my full CV on LinkedIn.

¬†

items.content_html:
Project Summary

The School of Museum Studies is the leading curatorial research centre in the UK. They want to expand their partnerships with universities in Asia. This project is a pilot study to understand how education partnerships form between universities and cultural organisations in Western and developing countries. I analysed how transnational curatorial education develop within emerging cultural centres, particularly in China, Qatar, and Saudi Arabia.¬†

Goal

Map out the landscape of transnational education in 3 months of project cycle. Develop a report that offers adivce on partnership research and development.

My Role
  • In-depth interviews & analysis
  • Policy research
  • Report writing¬†

Methods

Policy Review

I started by developing a spreadsheet covering current higher education programmes about museums and heritage at branch campuses of Western universities. I analysed institutional policy documents relating to their partners and course development.

Semi-structured Interview

From 30 education programmes analysed, I identified 7 case studies and conducted 8 semi-structured interviews with selected participants. This informed strategies for their future partnership-building.

Key Insights

  • Three types of transnational partnerships identified: branch campus, joint degree programmes, and professional training programmes.
  • Transnational education strengthened partnerships between universities, as well as between universities and local museums.
  • Local organisations had limited ownership of education programmes because most of the curriculum development was led by the Western institutions.
  • The pandemic, miscommunications, and different organisational cultures and policies posed significant challenges in partnership management.

Impact

We delivered a report that presented the landscape of transnational collaborations between universities, governments and cultural organisations in China and the Middle East.

Our report was featuerd in a panel discussion at the Anthropology and Education Conference 2024 (Royal Anthropological Institute, London). Our findings secured a funding for future development of the project.

¬†
